beenthere.description: Andrew Johnson's complex presidency (1865-69) illustrates the Constitution at work following the Civil War. As the President and Congress disagreed on Reconstruction methods, the Constitution served as their guide on balance of powers, vetoes, and impeachment. In the end, it evolved as a living document with pivotal amendments on freedom, citizenship, and voting rights - topics still vital today.

images.altText: Andrew Johnson Homestead with irises and flag
images.caption: Home of the 17th President from 1851-1875

images.title: Early Home
images.altText: Andrew Johnson's Early Home

images.altText: Andrew Johnson Monument

images.caption: The old caretaker's Lodge in the National Cemetery now serves as Park Headquarters

images.title: Andrew Johnson Museum

images.caption: The Museum tells the story of a controversial presidency

images.altText: A view of Monument Hill studded with veteran headstones

beenthere.name: Andrew Johnson

beenthere.description: On August 9, 1877 gun shots shattered a chilly dawn on a sleeping camp of Nez Perce. By the time the smoke cleared on August 10, almost 90 Nez Perce were dead along with 31 soldiers and volunteers. Big Hole National Battlefield was created to honor all who were there.

images.title: Battlefield at Dawn
images.altText: Multiple tepee poles and a river are silhouetted against a dawn sky.
images.caption: Today tepee poles stand sentinel at the site of August 9th, 1877 dawn attack at the Big Hole.

images.title: Camas Blooms Near the Nez Perce Camp at the Big Hole
images.altText: Blue camas flowers dot a green field with tepee poles in the background.
images.caption: The Nez Perce chose their camp site in the Big Hole in part due to the Camas, whose roots they gathered prior to the August 9th attack.

images.title: Mountain Howitzer at the Big Hole Battlefield
images.altText: a cannon overlooks a valley and distant mountains
images.caption: Nez Perce warriors captured and dismantled the Mountain Howitzer cannon before the US army could use it effectively at the Battle of the Big Hole.

images.title: Monument to the US Soldiers and Volunteers at the Big Hole Battlefield
images.altText: cross country skis rest against a large granite monument on a snowy day.
images.caption: In 1883 the United States Government erected this monument in honor of the soldiers and volunteers that served and died at the 1877 Battle of the Big Hole.

images.title: Chief Joseph Memorial at the Big Hole Battlefield
images.altText: Stone carving of a Nez Perce Warrior's head in full regalia.
images.caption: This monument, erected on the Big Hole Battlefield in 1928, reads; "To the everlasting memory of the brave warriors Chief Joseph's Band who fought on these grounds in the Nez Perce War of 1877."

images.title: Bear Paw Battlefield
images.altText: Three large stone monuments and four interpretive signs overlook a series of low hills.

beenthere.name: Big Hole

beenthere.description: Bandelier National Monument protects over 33,000 acres of rugged but beautiful canyon and mesa country as well as evidence of a human presence here going back over 11,000 years. Petroglyphs, dwellings carved into the soft rock cliffs, and standing masonry walls pay tribute to the early days of a culture that still survives in the surrounding communities.

images.title: Tyuonyi
images.altText: the village of Tyuonyi
images.caption: A view of Tyuonyi and the cliff dwelling in Frijoles Canyon from the mesa.

images.title: View from a Cavate
images.altText: Tyuonyi from a cavate
images.caption: A view of Tyuonyi from a cavate along the Main Loop Trail in Frijoles Canyon.

images.title: Long House
images.altText: archeological sites in Frijoles Canyon
images.caption: A view of Long House dwellings from the mesa top.

images.title: Frijoles Canyon
images.altText: a view of Frijoles Canyon from the rim
images.caption: A view of Frijoles Canyon from the Frey Trail

images.title: Cerro Grande
images.altText: a view of the Valles Caldera from Cerro Grande
images.caption: A view of the Valles Caldera from Cerro Grande, the highest point in Bandelier.

images.title: The Rio Grande
images.altText: a view of the Rio Grande
images.caption: A view of the Rio Grande, the lowest point in Bandelier, from the mesa above Frijoles Canyon

images.title: Visitor Center
images.altText: visitor center in winter
images.caption: Bandelier visitor center in winter

beenthere.name: Bandelier

beenthere.description: For nearly 5,000 years, people have lived in these canyons - longer than anyone has lived uninterrupted anywhere on the Colorado Plateau. In the place called Tsegi, their homes and images tell us their stories. Today, Navajo families make their homes, raise livestock, and farm the lands in the canyons. A place like no other, the park and Navajo Nation work together to manage the land's resources.

images.title: Canyon Farm
images.altText: Farm in the canyon
images.caption: Navajo families continue to live and farm in the canyon they call Tsegi

images.title: Canyon Hike
images.altText: Hiking in the canyon
images.caption: Visitors can enjoy a free ranger led hike into the canyon

images.title: Spider Rock
images.altText: View of Spider Rock from the overlook
images.caption: Her home on top of Spider Rock, Spider Woman taught the Navajo people how to weave

images.title: Canyon View
images.altText: View of the canyon from the White House Trail
images.caption: The Navajo people call the canyon Tsegi meaning "within the rocks"

images.title: White House
images.altText: View of White House Ruin
images.caption: Ancient Puebloans built villages like White House that offered opportunities for trade, ceremony, and social gatherings.

beenthere.name: Canyon de Chelly

bucketlist.description: Located at the confluence of two rivers, Arkansas Post has served as a gathering place for many cultures throughout human history - it represents cultural cooperation, conflict, synthesis, and diversity.

images.title: Arkansas Post National Monument
images.altText: confluence of two rivers
images.caption: Located at the confluence of two rivers, Arkansas Post has served as a gathering place for many cultures.

images.title: Arkansas Post National Monument
images.altText: the Alligator Slough footbridge
images.caption: The Alligator Slough footbridge

images.title: Arkansas Post National Monument
images.altText: Arkansas Post National Memorial is in the Lower Mississippi Riverine Forest ecoregion.
images.caption: Located at the confluence of two rivers, Arkansas Post has served as a gathering place for many cultures throughout human history - it represents cultural cooperation, conflict, synthesis, and diversity.

images.title: Arkansas Post National Monument
images.altText: Over the three centuries of history at Arkansas Post, the area has been greatly changed by both natu
images.caption: Located at the northern edge of the Gulf coastal plain, the Arkansas Post's native growth ranges from prairie grasses and lowland hardwood forests to wetland marshes near the bayous and river.

images.title: Living History
images.altText: Arkansas Post National Monument cannon firing
images.caption: During the Civil War, Confederate troops tried to maintain tactical control of the confluence of the Arkansas and White Rivers, and in 1862 they constructed a massive earthen fortification known as Fort Hindman at the Post. In January 1863 Union troops d

bucketlist.name: Arkansas Post

bucketlist.description: Amache, also known as the Granada Relocation Center, near Granada, Colorado was one of ten incarceration sites established by the War Relocation Authority during World War II to unjustly incarcerate Japanese Americans. Over 10,000 people, most American citizens, were incarcerated at Amache from 1942-1945. Amache - a place to reflect, recommit, and further the pursuit of freedom and justice.

images.title: Amache Barracks and Guard Tower
images.altText: reconstructed barracks, guard and water towers surrounded by brown grass and shrubs.
images.caption: Reconstructed barracks, guard and water towers at the newly designated Amache National Historic Site

bucketlist.name: Amache

bucketlist.description: Established in 1972, Buffalo National River flows freely for 135 miles and is one of the few remaining undammed rivers in the lower 48 states. Once you arrive, prepare to journey from running rapids to quiet pools while surrounded by massive bluffs as you cruise through the Ozark Mountains down to the White River.

images.title: Indian Rockhouse
images.altText: A large bluff shelter near Buffalo Point.
images.caption: Every year thousands of people hike to the Indian Rockhouse to admire this large bluff shelter.

images.title: Skull Rock
images.altText: Kayakers floating towards Skull Rock near Buffalo Point.
images.caption: A peaceful day on the Buffalo River as kayakers approach Skull Rock and Buffalo Point.

images.title: Steel Creek Campground
images.altText: Camping at Steel Creek
images.caption: Camping along the Buffalo River is a wonderful way to enjoy the park.

images.title: Floating the Buffalo
images.altText: Floaters on the river.
images.caption: Canoeing and kayaking the river is a wonderful way to spend a day at the Buffalo.

images.title: Sod Collier Homestead
images.altText: Historic homestead built by the Collier Family.
images.caption: Many historic structures are scattered along the Buffalo River reminding us of the hardworking settlers that once called this river valley home.

images.title: Smallmouth Bass Fishing
images.altText: Fisherman with smallmouth bass.
images.caption: Fishing for smallmouth bass is a popular activity on the Buffalo River.

bucketlist.name: Buffalo

bucketlist.description: The great Outer Beach described by Thoreau in the 1800s is protected within the national seashore. Forty miles of pristine sandy beach, marshes, ponds, and uplands support diverse species. Lighthouses, cultural landscapes, and wild cranberry bogs offer a glimpse of Cape Cod's past and continuing ways of life. Swimming beaches and walking and biking trails beckon today's visitors.

images.title: Sunrise Waves
images.altText: A curling wave breaks against the backdrop of a pink sunrise.
images.caption: Visiting the beach to watch the sunrise over the Atlantic Ocean is a beautiful experience.

images.title: Sand Ripples
images.altText: Low tide exposes rippled ridges of sand and water.
images.caption: You will never walk the same beach twice on Cape Cod; daily low and high tides expose and then cover the sand.

images.title: Exploring the Park by Water
images.altText: A red kayak floats on a pond facing a forest colored with red and orange leaves.
images.caption: Exploring the park by water offers a different perspective.

images.title: Birds and Beach
images.altText: A flock of birds flies along a beach with waves in the background.
images.caption: The national seashore is known for its species diversity, including threatened and endangered shorebirds.

images.title: Atlantic White Cedar Swamp Trail
images.altText: Boardwalk trail runs through a swamp surrounded by green ferns and tall trees.
images.caption: This popular trail takes visitors through the rare habitat of an Atlantic White Cedar swamp.

images.title: Sunrise Over the Atlantic
images.altText: A brilliant sun rises over the ocean reflecting light on the water's surface.
images.caption: Cape Cod provides the opportunity to watch the sun rise out of the Atlantic Ocean and set into Cape Cod Bay.

bucketlist.name: Cape Cod

bucketlist.description: . . . where you can walk a Civil War-era fort, visit historic lighthouses, explore tide pools, hike lush trails, camp under the stars, or relax while fishing, picnicking or swimming-all within reach of downtown Boston. Youth programs, visitor services, research, wildlife management, and more are coordinated on the park's 34 islands and peninsulas by the Boston Harbor Islands Partnership.

images.title: Beach Dancing
images.altText: A child dancing on the beach at dusk
images.caption: A child dancing on the beach at dusk

images.title: Kayaking Boston Harbor Islands
images.altText: A man on a kayak in Boston Harbor
images.caption: Kayaking in Boston Harbor Islands National Recreational Area

images.title: Sunset Over Boston
images.altText: An image of the sun setting over the Boston skyline from the Islands
images.caption: Watch the sunset from Boston Harbor Islands

images.title: Come Explore The Islands
images.altText: Children looking out at Boston from the Harbor Islands
images.caption: Looking out at the city from the Boston Harbor Islands

images.title: Fort Warren
images.altText: Historic Fort Warren on Georges Island
images.caption: Visit historic Fort Warren on Georges Island in Boston Harbor

bucketlist.name: Boston Harbor Islands
